comments.commentBody:
Caucus's rarely if ever have large turnouts...
Nothing new to report there
A Democratic Caucus is nothing more than a left wing fringe gathering
just as a Republican Caucus is a party for all the Right Wing Nuts to come out of their survival bunkers for a couple of hours...

Indeed, I can think of a reason Sanders did as well as he did in Colorado that has gone completely unmentioned: Sanders supports the federal full legalization of marijuana, and Colorado has been living with a state-wide legalization now for a few years. That means that marijuana growers and distributors in Colorado are in an odd spot where they are legal in the state, except if the feds change their minds and decide to go after them (Obama has directed the FBI to not go after marijuana in places where there is compliance with state law, but the next president could change that). Because of that legal ambiguity, everyone in the industry is unable to, for example, open up bank accounts for their business.

Policy matters in political races. Horse-race reporting doesn't acknowledge that simple fact.
Absolutely no mention of the considerable delegate counts from CO and MN -- because they don't really fit into the narrative being repeated mindlessly in the NYTimes these days.  What's up?

I see more wisdom in some of these comments that I recognize in Minxin Pei’s responses. His forecast to date have been blunted by the persistence of the CCP long existence, beyond the history of other communist systems. While the hammer and cycle is still there for backdrop Marxian Communism died somewhere along the path in the early 1990’s.
What persist is a CCP with no alternatives in view, and the best description of it is a tight Leninist grouping searching for policy solutions to a rapidly developing country in an autocratic manner.
They will of necessity evolve into differing forms as they did under Jiang when he opened the party to Capitalists, but autocracy has a long history here and China is not doing too poorly on the economic stage, whatever the real growth rate, it is still way out in front.
Corruption you may have noticed seems to be less shocking in Asia than elsewhere.
Even now the front page only shows two of his wins. You have to click "more" to see he won four.
And why is using the term "Berniebots" helpful and adult?
It's not bias, but prescience. Hillary is clearly going to win, whether Bernie supporters think so or not. Even Trump assumes this.

I really had faith that the NY Times would not pander to bias and yet that's all its been, even before the Editorial Board decided to come out in favor of Hillary months before this moment.  Shame on me for trusting the integrity of such a great institution I've been reading for more than 30 years.

Obviously, it is not. But it has SOME Democrats and they went for Bernie. A bit surprising, as he could not carry liberal Massachusetts. But MA is almost all Democrat, and Oklahoma probably only has a few thousand in the whole state. It's a victory amongst a small minority. In the general election, Oklahoma will go hard right GOP.
Go Bernie Sanders go! Look America, even the state of Oklahoma knows how to do the right thing when it really comes down to beating politics-as-usual in this great country. Thank you Oklahoma.
The liberals who live in Oklahoma are the liberal stronghold.
I didn't realize Oklahoma was a liberal stronghold.

Pdxtran, keep in mind that we're not talking about Oklahoma voters generally, but Democratic Oklahoma voters.  Perhaps they're especially liberal Democrats, or they may have strong populist leanings, which Bernie could also appeal to.

Now this is getting strange. I keep reading this EXACT same comment over and over again -- VERBATIM.
Looks like the mind-fix is in.
Ellen, you are right -- on both counts.
Sanders won liberal states ...like Oklahoma?
Hillary reminds you of Margaret Thatcher.  Is that some kind of joke?  The "stand by your man " candidate.  The one riding the coattails of her husband?  Hillary Clinton is no Margaret Thatcher.

Thank you for drawing this analogy. There is one big difference between them. One of the only things I found admirable about Thatcher was that she made her way to the top independently, skillfully using the support of male political mentors but with no powerful family to pave her path. Hillary Clinton floated her way into electoral politics on her husband's back. I wish our first female president could be a woman like Elizabeth Warren, recognized and elevated entirely for her own accomplishments.
Nonsense!  "Women's rights are human rights, and human rights are women's rights."
Hillary reminds me of Margaret Thatcher. Both of them are/were brave. Both of them are/were tough. But neither of them are/were right.

If one believed the MSM, Sanders should have lost all the Super Tuesday states except Vermont.  Yet supporters poured millions into his campaign just the day before.  And we will keep doing so.  We are in this down through the convention, and I am sure I am not alone in planning to write Bernie in if Her Smirkingness gets the nomination,
It is called whistling past the graveyard. In the words of a famous Germany propagandist, if you repeat a lie often enough, people will believe it is true.
And where was that revolution in seven states yesterday?

Your last paragraph is counterintuitive.

"People close to Mrs. Clinton believe that Mr. Sanders’s fund-raising prowess will diminish after his losses on Tuesday, preventing him from continuing to challenge her until the convention in July, a possibility that appeared plausible early last month when he raised $8 million in online donations in the 48 hours after his 22-point victory in New Hampshire."

It appeared plausible that he would stop raising money after he raised 8 million in 48 hours, basically unheard of?

Your bias is showing, maybe with the money from the shiny Clinton campaign you can buy yourself some sparkly new Hillary Clinton 2016 cheerleading outfits.
Even Massachusets turned green for a while, which didn't reflect the numbers!

Great, pithy essay.  The cynical power grab that began with Ronald Reagan's coded campaign of bigotry with his "Morning in America," and that was aided and abetted in every election large and small by party loyalty without reason, that turned language upside down, and even now hypocritically blames our President for the divisions between us, is as stark now as it's ever been.
Amen and well said.  Lincoln is rolling in his grave because of what has become of the GOP.

Well said.  I would add one very important point though.  This is the party of fiscal hypocrisy, that rails against deficit spending while out of power, then runs up debt levels by slashing tax rates for the wealthy and increasing spending while in power.  Maintaining this hypocritical attitude while campaigning as the party of fiscal responsibility is the single biggest reason that this country's debt level is so high.  Why so many Americans remain in denial on this point is baffling.

“This party does not prey on people’s prejudices. We appeal to their highest ideals. This is the party of Lincoln.”

How dare you, Mr. Ryan.

This is the party that preyed on fear of gay people to get out the evangelical vote by putting gay marriage measures on state ballots in the 1990s. This is the party that embraced Rush Limbaugh and all his demagoguery and hatred and divisiveness. This is the party that spat out the word "liberal" as if it was spelled with four letters. This is the party that gave us a president who preyed on fear of people in far-off lands, who took advantage of a national tragedy that should have led to our greatest hour, and sent us to war without end that has made this world a more dangerous place. This is the party that has presided while wealth in this nation has concentrated at the very top to a degree unprecedented in U.S. history--the Democrats certainly helped, sure, but the Republicans did nary a thing to stop it and, in fact, did everything possible to ensure it.

This is not the party of Lincoln, Mr. Ryan. Abraham Lincoln would be throwing fits and helping form a new party, just as the Whigs were replaced by Republicans so long ago, if he could see what the GOP has become. This is a party that has richly earned what is coming to it now.

Do not disgrace the name of Abraham Lincoln by claiming that the Republican Party of the 21st century is the party of the greatest president in U.S. history. We've had enough lies from the GOP.

Way to go Dan! One should never feel ashamed to use a tool -- any tool -- to solve a problem. I know someone with a PhD in physics who shows middle and high school students how to use Excel to simulate diffusion, a thermodynamics concept. Since part of the school year I help 5th grade students learn how to use a spreadsheet, I will now add your solution to my repertoire of examples. So thank you very much! Since we apparently live in the same town, I hope to catch up with you sometime!
P.S.: I hope you got a good night's sleep!
Ooops. I meant Don, not Dan. Regardless, Nice!

I'm not an active math guy, but used an excel sheet to help me.  First column, first row had a starting number of my choice.  Second column subtracted the correct number of pearls based on the specific daughter (1 through whatever).  Third column calculated the remaining number of pearls.  Fourth column always divided by 7.  Fifth column was the value of dividing the remaining pearls by 7.  Sixth column added the number of pearls subtracted in column 2 to the number of pearls in column 5.  The number in column 6 was subtracted from the number in column 1 and then placed into the next row of column 1, and all of the formulas were duplicated, adjusting only for the number of subtracted pearls.  I knew I needed numbers that were always divisible by 7 in column 3.  Not very pretty, but neither am I.  I know nothing of slopes or mathematical formulas.  The point is I used some creative thought and tools I understand to get the correct answer by simply manipulating the value in first column of the first row.  I went as high as 200 in row 1 column 1 before I realized he only had a reasonable number of daughters.  Now I'm going to bed.

I'm not a Clinton supporter. I support getting a Democrat in the White House.

I don't think "stool pigeon" is the phrase you were going for, but keep trying.
Yes, Colorado is liberal in terms of the Mountain Time Zone-- but it is a swing state nationally. For the Times to term Colorado as a liberal bastion is laughable.
More appropriately:  "Clinton wins in conservative strongholds of the south"
"Sanders wins in Liberal Strongholds" says the Times. Liberal strongholds like Oklahoma and Colorado?  More egregious Clinton propaganda from the Times.
You are absolutely correct that the hard core left is actively antagonising and pushing white men away.

The GOP has been in crises for decades as it has presented itself as representing the middle class year after year as it sold out America for the benefit of the wealthiest few. People still don't get it.

Wow.  One would've thought 2000 and the Ralph Nader experience of putting Bush into the WH for 8 destructive years would've helped avoid such asinine sentiments.  Clinton doesn't need to be your hero (she certainly isn't mine).  You don't even have to like her!  Just be an adult and think beyond yourself and do  the right thing.  Not because she's the best choice.  But because, looking across at the GOP-sadistic-clown-car, she's the better one.  Unless, of course, you don't mind having Trump as president.  But then, what does that say about your support for Bernie, a man of principle, and ideas?  And someone who I fully expect will endorse Clinton when he can no longer win, because he knows what's best for the nation, and isn't interested in petty 'payback' when things don't go his way.  That's a statesman worthy of respect.  And you, threatening to stand on the sidelines because your guy didn't win, don't deserve him.
We can thank SCOTUS for throwing the 2000 election to Bush, a reminder of the enormous importance of taking the court out of reactionary, corporate friendly hands.
You're kidding right????? A SoS with a private service to hide her emails from public disclosure is not in the gutter. It's criminal and she's being investigated by the FBI.

GOP--the party of obstructionism, vote suppression, birther movement, rebellion against authority (such as the president’s), and other unpleasant activities—is now reaping what it has sown: it’s rank and file members are supporting two candidates reviled by the GOP establishment, Trump and Cruz.

Marco Rubio, the latest GOP establishment choice for the party nomination, hasn’t won a primary yet, at least as of 11PM on March 1st, demonstrating how out of touch the party leadership is with its members.

It is all well and good that the party has a majority in the Congress and a majority of the state houses, but winning by pitting one group against another hasn’t done anything to win the hearts and minds of its own members.

Perhaps it is finally time for the GOP to try to become the party of Lincoln that it was before it further erodes what little respect the party has left among the public at large.

As for the Democratic party, Mrs. Clinton had better realize that those supporting Senator Sanders, not merely by voting for him but by making individual small dollar contributions that have been funding his campaign, are fed up with the party’s reliance on--and beholden to--Super PACs for campaign financing, not to mention her own questionable relationship with big business. If Mrs. Clinton fails to address the issues raised by Sanders, she risks losing the Sanders voters’ support and thus the general election.

Just who are these unnamed Republican leaders that should have taken control of the party rather than leaving it to voters?  Surly not Paul Ryan, clearly a member of the dark side.  You must mean the big money interests.  Have they been sitting on the sidelines?  Not what I've been reading.
I recently read a biography of Lincoln, and I truly think that he would have a very dim view of the current pack of con men and blatherscaphs that are are passing themselves off as Republicans.
Lots of progressive 1%ers out there, especially in Seattle.

You point out that Rubio and Cruz are to the right of Trump so why try to stop him if you are a Republican voter who does not want Medicare and SS abolished, as those two would do and Trump would  not? I do not think there is an difference between Trump and the other two, and the pathetic Ben Carson and Kasich are clowns without any more humanity.  When it comes to primaries Trump seems to be expressing the sentiments the Republicans have always embraced: racism, bigotry, anti-democracy in denying votes to citizens, foreign policy failures and war mongers, to name only a few of the defects. As far as cutting off his knees before he got out his message, none of the 16 other candidates had very much to offer or they would be the nominee, not Trump. We can hope that Trump will win the nomination, lose badly to Hillary and help destroy what is left of the Republican party.
Nicely done!

@Nr: "Will Lee Atwater speak from the heavens?"

The heavens? Try again.
Benjamin - Some nice ideas here.  But it isn't accurate.   Obama didn't cripple the Republicans. Their inability to separate church from state did.

I said something like this about the GOP establishment in another comment elsewhere and it bears repeating here.

Speaker Ryan sounds like Claude Rains in "Casablanca" declaring that he is shocked that gambling is going on in Humphrey Bogart's nightclub.
